doc.field: <description type="note">Preliminaries, introductory and editorial matter omitted<lb/>Source texts incomplete<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:</description>

Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
<description type="note">There are no identifiable speakers in this play.</description>

<description type="note">Angle brackets represent sections of text unclear in the original and supplied by a previous or the current editor.<lb/>Square brackets represent sections of text which have been left defective by the scribe and supplied by a previous or the current editor.</description>

I. Emperourys and kyngys be kende, Erlys and barunnys bolde, Bachelerys and knytys to mende, Sueyerys and ?emen to holde, Knauys and pagys to sende, So parfyt Ã¾at aryn to be solde, I prey ?ow, lordyngys so hende, No yangelyngys ?e mak in Ã¾is folde To-day; Als ?e are louely in fas, Set ?ow alle semly in plas, And I xal withoutyn falas Schewe resounus here to ?oure pay. Welthys I welde at my wylle, In word I am knowyn ful wyde, I aue hert and hynd vpon hille, I am gay on grounde for to glyde; Semly Ã¾er I syt vpon sille, My wyf and my menÃ© be my syde. I [commaund] ?ow tende me tylle, Or ellys I xal bate ?owre pride Wyt dynt, And Ã¾erfor I warne ?ow infere Ãat ?e mak neyÃ¾er criyng ne bere. If ?e do, withoutyn duere, Strokys at ?ow xal I mynt. Duk Morawd I hot be name, Korteyser lord may be none, Wol fer Ã¾an rengnyt my fame, To be comly korownyt from one. I geue gode gyftys with game And saue iche lordyng fro fone, Me bowyn boÃ¾e wylde and tame, QueÃ¾ire so Ã¾ei rydyn er gone Ore scheppe. I am dowty in dede, I am worly in wede, I am semly on stede, No weleny to me wyl I kyppe. II. Dam, do now Ã¾i wylle Ãi wyage to fulfylle, To Ã¾e wyl I be beyne. For loue I Ã¾e pray: Rap Ã¾e faste in Ã¾i way, And cum hom sone ageyne. III. Thorow Ã¾e grace of Ã¾at ich Kyngk Ãat formyt vs alle with wenne, I xal me kepyn from fondyng And als from blame and synne With gras. Jhesu, als Ã¾ou me wrowtys And with woundys sore me bowtys, Saue me fro wykyt thowtys, Jhesu, fayr in fas! IV. Fare wel, my worlych wyf, Fare wel, loue jn lond, Fare Ã¾ou, semlyest lyf, Fare Ã¾ou happy in hond! V. Maydyn so louely and komly of syte, I prey Ã¾e for loue Ã¾ou wyl lystyn to me; To here my resun I prey Ã¾e wel tythe, Loue so deryn me most schewe to Ã¾e; My loue to Ã¾i body is castyn so bryth, My wyl me most aue of Ã¾e. Ãou art louely to leykyn and brythest with ryth, I loue Ã¾e in thowt, Ã¾ou semly of ble, Be name. Ãou maydyn Ã¾at moryst Ã¾i merthis with myth, Derne dedys me most do be day and be nyth Be Ã¾e worÃ¾iest woundyn, wytthest wytâ The soÃ¾e tale I telle withoutyn ony blame. VI. My fere so graciouse in gras, Thanc Ã¾ou xalt auen of me, For Ã¾ou art louely in fas And Ã¾erto bryth berende of ble. Now wyl I makyn solas, For my deryn loue xalt Ã¾ou be. Kys me now par amour in plas, Als Ã¾ou art worly to se In syte. Damysel, fayrest to fonde, Als Ã¾ou art semly to stonde, Rap we vs to wendyn in honde To Ã¾i chambyr Ã¾at is so louely of lythe. VII. A! I am wondyn in gret dolour, With danger and tene I am bownde. To me Ã¾ou geue tent par amowr, And lystne quat I sey Ã¾is stounde! ?on traytowr xal bewrey vs Ã¾is oure, I telle Ã¾e, semly on grownde; Ãan xul we aue no socowr, But carys to vs xal be fownde, Iwys. I ne may neuer be fawe Tyl yon traytowr be slaw Ãat is so rebel in sawe; Sorows mot ay to her kys. VIII. Â«AÂ»uesÂ«toÂ»w now slayne, be Ã¾i fay, Ãe fol Ã¾at dede vs Ã¾at tene? IX. A! Now am I mery Ã¾is stound, Ãat che is browt to Ã¾at ded, For che suld a wreyd vs on grownd, Ãat ilke old schrewed qued, To sorowe che xuld vs a foundâ Ãat adde ben to vs an ewyl red; In care forsoÃ¾e is che wownd, And Ã¾erfor I am mery to led And gay. Â«DÂ»amysel, louely of chere, Mak we mery here, For care, withoutyn duere, Is went awey for ay. X. A! Aue I begotyn Ã¾is stownd A schyld so louely of Ã¾e, I am in sorows wownd, For care me most fle. I prey Ã¾e in welth now wownd, Ãat fot in syt myth I se. XI. Aa, Â«byrdÂ» fayr and bryt, Do it out of my syt, For thowt I am ny sclawe! Â«SÂ»clo it in presentâ Ãat is my cowmaundementâ Fast bry[n]g it of dawe! For al Ã¾is lond I wold nowt Ãat lordys of Ã¾is lond ad yt thowt, Ãat I ad synd be Ã¾e. For serow and care Ã¾at we xuld drywe We xuld led euer lyf ful rywe And Ã¾eron ay to be. Ãerfor I prey Ã¾e, For Â«Ã¾iÂ» loue of me, Slo yt with Ã¾in hond! ÃaÂ«nÂ» xul we ben in pes, Withoutyn ony lees, And auyn merth in lond. XII. Â«In es???al???Â» syng Ãer I sytte louely in thowr, I thang Ã¾e, louely Ã¾[i]ng, For Ã¾i wÂ«eÂ»rkyngys Ã¾is oure. For Ã¾at parfyt tydyng I geue Ã¾e allys and bowr, For Ã¾ou, withoutyn lesyng, Pottyst me fro scham and dolowr. XIII. In to kontrÃ© I wyl wend, Ãer to plete boÃ¾e fer and hend, With god dÂ«edysÂ» boun. Ãer as it comyt in my mend For to mete with lordys kynd BoÃ¾e in fylde and toun. XIV. Betyd me god, Into contrÃ© But I prey Ã¾e Ã¾is oure, My der paramowre, I xal no more Ã¾at But sertys I xal fond Withoutyn Â«Ha godÂ»day, worlych wyth! Ha godday, louely in lyth! Par semly in syth, comly . XV. I am mythful and mery markyd in mynd, I am flour fayrest be fryt for to fare, I am fayrest in fas, ferly to fynd, I am loueliche in lond, lyttest in lare, I am comly and curteys and crafty of kynd, I am comly castyn fro knottys of care, I am lordly to leykyn lyt vndyr lynd, I am semly to syttun syttys so sare, I wyl pres me in pride! Quan alle Ã¾e lordys of Ã¾is lond are gadered infere, I am flour of hem alle withoutyn duere, And ellys I were woxyn of blamys ryt here But I be ryal in rayis forto ryde. XVI. A! now I here A belle ryngant ful nere, ?endyr in Ã¾e kyrk. ÃeÃ¾er I wyl fare, For I am in gret care Ãer sum god ded to werk. XVII. A synful kaytyf I am, Synfully I aue wrowt blam Be gret tyme of my lyfe. Now, Cryst, ast Ã¾ou me bowt; Forgeue me Ã¾at blam Ã¾at I aue wrowt, And mak me sumquat blyÃ¾e! For in Ã¾is werd may be none, Ãat euer tok lyf with flesch and bone, Ãat auyt so gret blam. But I aue gras and help of Ã¾e, I am lost fro Ã¾e so fre, In helle to be be nam. A prest now me most aue, If [I] xal be saue Ageynus Cryst of myth, To telle hym my blam Ãat I aue wrowt be nam, Ãat is my thowt now tyth To-day! Jhesu, heuene-flowr, Pot me from dolour, And geue me gras Ã¾is o[u]re A prest to auyn, I say! XVIII. A! Blyssyd be Ã¾ou ay, Ãat Ã¾ou com to-day To here my dedly syn! Quylys we are infere, I wyl schrywe me here, For now wil I begyn. I aue led my lyf In sorow and in stryf, With cursydnessys and care; ?et is more in my th[o]wt, Synnus I aue wrowt Be my douter in lare. And chyld che bar be me, Quyk was fayr and fre BoÃ¾e in body and fas, And I myt neuer be fawe Tyl we had hym sclaweâ I sey Ã¾e soÃ¾e cas! ?et more I wyl telle now. My wyf Ã¾er che sclow Thowr egment of me. And Ã¾us is my lyf spendâ Lord omnipotent, Grant me my synnus to fle. XIX. I wyl blely, my leue frend, Do penawns boÃ¾e fer and hend, To saue my sowle fro wratÂ«hÂ». XX. Heyl douter, louely of syt. Heyl, louely leuende to-day, Cryst Ã¾at is mytty in myt Saue Ã¾e ermor and ay! XXI. Lat be, my douter dere, Lat be, louely in lere, I aue forsakyn here My blam and my syn. My syn I aue forsake, And to penawns I aue me take, For Ã¾at wykkyd wrake Now is time to blyn. And Ã¾erfor I prey Ã¾e, Sertys with herte fre, Ãat Ã¾ou mak not me To falle in nomor blam! Now wyl I don away My tresorys rych and gay, And traueylyn I wyl ay For my wykyt fam. XXII. Now my lyf wyl passe Fro me Ã¾is ilk stonde, I am smetyn in Ã¾e fas With carful strokys and rownde. Jhesu ful of gras Forgeue Ã¾e Ã¾is trespas Ãat Ã¾ou ast don to me, And geue Ã¾e gras to blyn Of Ã¾at wykyd syn Quylk Ã¾ou ast don so fre. My tyme comyt faste to Ãat I xal pas ?ow fro, In oÃ¾ir plas to duelle. In manus tuas, domine! Jhesu haue mercy on me, And saue my sowle fro helle.
